åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼š

https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/qViwWPFMEhN_Y2HJKdYRiA

Is having a cry good for our health?

Until recently, scientists and authors were at stark disagreement over the point of crying. In King Henry VI, Shakespeare wrote, â€œto weep is to make less the depth of griefâ€, and the American writer Lemony Snicket said â€œunless you have been very, very lucky, you know that a good, long session of weeping can often make you feel better, even if your circumstances have not changed one bitâ€.

Charles Darwin, on the other hand, thought that the production of tears (the act of crying notwithstanding) was merely a useless side effect of the way that the muscles around the eye worked. For him, those muscles had to contract from time to time so that they didnâ€™t overflow with blood; the expulsion of tears was simply an unintended consequence of that evolved physiological process. (He did acknowledge that crying could help young infants attract the attention of their parents, though.)

We now know that crying â€“ at least, the sort that adults do â€“ is a complex physiological response to some kind of emotional stimulus. The most prominent feature is of course the shedding of tears, but it also includes changes in facial expressions and breathing patterns. â€œSobbing,â€ for example, refers to the rapid inhalation and exhalation that so often accompanies crying.

From a scientific perspective, that means crying is different from the production of tears in response to a chemical irritant, like when you accidentally rub your eyes after eating spicy foods. Even the tears themselves are different. In 1981, Minnesota psychiatrist William H Frey II discovered that tears brought on by sad movies had more protein in them than those that flowed in response to some freshly chopped onions.

As anyone who has attended a side-splitting comedy act or listened to a groom read wedding vows to his bride, emotional tears arenâ€™t limited to feelings of melancholy. But while all of us are familiar with the feelings that are associated with crying, whether for joy or sorrow, thereâ€™s not much thatâ€™s known about why we do it as adults â€“ but there are plenty of ideas.

One idea is that adult crying isnâ€™t actually all that different from the sort that babies do, at least when it comes to its social nature. In other words, perhaps weeping is a literal cry for attention, a means of soliciting support and help from our friends when we need it the most. Itâ€™s a way of communicating our inner emotional state at a time when we may not be able to fully articulate it.

While this may explain some forms of crying, many researchers have found that adults often cry when theyâ€™re completely alone. Another possibility that is that crying might serve as a means of â€œsecondary appraisal,â€ helping people to realise just how upset they are, a way of helping them understand their own feelings â€“ itâ€™s a provocative idea, with at least some evidence to support it, in some cases.

And then thereâ€™s the notion of catharsis: crying provides for relief from emotionally stressful situations. The idea is consistent not only with the words of Shakespeare, but with the Roman poet Ovid, who wrote: â€œIt is a relief to weep; grief is satisfied and carried off by tears.â€ The Greek philosopher Aristotle also wrote that crying â€œcleanses the mindâ€. In a 1986 study of popular US magazines and newspapers, one psychologist found that 94% of articles about crying suggested that it helped to relieve psychological tension.

Indeed, a 2008 study of nearly 4,300 young adults from 30 countries found that most reported improvements in both their mental and physical wellbeing after a bout of crying, but not all. Some reported no change after a crying session, and some even said that they felt worse afterwards.

The difference seems to lie in the social context: if a person felt embarrassed about crying in public, for example, they might feel less resolved than if they cried alone or with a single close friend. The study also found that when people tried to suppress or hide their crying, they also wound up feeling less relief afterwards.

So the notion of having â€œa good cryâ€ is not without merit, but it seems to necessitate the right kind of social support to be effective. Which means, in the end, that adults might just cry for much the same reason as human infants: to seek help from their friends and family.

entry.content:
åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼šhttps://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/4-TvzjkUt10mhQVy2Mg-hA

Will This Be the â€˜Indian Centuryâ€™? Four Key Questions

It is a turning point the world has not seen in centuries, and is unlikely to see again for centuries more.

India is on the cusp of passing China in population, according to the latest U.N. estimates. At 1.428 billion people, India has already edged past Chinaâ€™s mainland, the data show.

With Chinaâ€™s population declining, the margin between the two countries will only grow as India becomes the most populous country in history. What had long been the worldâ€™s largest democracy is now, simply, the worldâ€™s largest everything.

Can India take advantage of its size?

Indiaâ€™s growth curve is the envy of aging countries like China, but the demographic future differs by region of the country.

There was a time when India and China wanted to suppress the rate of population growth, by reducing the number of births. That era has long receded.

The gentle slope of the demographic curve propelling India into first place looks enviable to the many developed nations that are rapidly aging. Indians are living longer, and the number of babies being born each year has barely budged.

In some of Indiaâ€™s regions, the population is still growing too fast for their economies, producing many more able-bodied young people than there are jobs to occupy them. In other parts, however â€“ especially the better-developed south, where women have more education and family planning programs have proved successful â€“ the population has already peaked. There, young families rarely produce more than two children.

The physical needs of nearly a billion and a half people are imposing a terrible strain on Indiaâ€™s environment. But as the country lifts itself from deepest poverty, it is no longer subject to the famines of old. Instead, its future as far and away the worldâ€™s biggest work force is leading some to hope for an â€œIndian centuryâ€ in the making.

Does India stand to reap a â€œdemographic dividendâ€?

Having a fast-expanding young work force could be a big opportunity â€” or a disaster.

India is a country primed to work. More than two-thirds of all Indians are between the ages of 15 and 59. The countryâ€™s ratio of children and retirees to working-age adults is remarkably low.

But this opportunity comes with huge challenges. That â€œdemographic dividendâ€ could instead become something like a disaster. In some recent years, India has squeaked past China to claim the title of fastest-growing major economy. But it has never expanded fast enough to produce sufficient formal employment for everyone. The country needs about nine million new jobs every year just to keep pace; the annual shortfall helps relegate many to Indiaâ€™s old standby, agricultural work.

Most people in India lack the means to be â€œunemployedâ€ â€“ in the work force but without a job. Underemployment is the more discreet danger. Wages have been stagnant for eight years, according to an analysis by Jean DrÃ¨ze, an economist at Delhi University. Economic growth without an equivalent increase in jobs makes Indiaâ€™s massively unequal society even more so, raising the potential for unrest.

Can India get more women into the work force?

Women work outside the home at lower rates in India than almost any other country, a huge roadblock for economic expansion.

India has one of the worldâ€™s lowest rates of formal employment for women: about one in five. Chinaâ€™s is almost double that rate, higher than the United Statesâ€™ and the world average. An economy cannot meet its potential when it draws on the contributions of so few women.

Also worrisome, the rate has actually declined in India even as most of the countryâ€™s economic conditions have improved. The explanation favored by economists is that the jobs most women take are so poorly paid that as soon as a family can do without the extra income, wives stop working outside the home.

That does not mean women in India do not work hard. They are a visible presence in the 41 percent of society that is still in agriculture, and they carry nearly all of the household burdens. But so long as these women remain outside the formal work force, they cannot enter its most productive categories, in industry and services. Improved access to family planning, better education, efforts to change societal attitudes and measures to ensure womenâ€™s safety could help more women take on formal work.

Can India chart its own path to prosperity?

Indiaâ€™s economic story will not be a repetition of Chinaâ€™s â€” which could offer advantages.

Western countries are now rushing to embrace India as an alternative to China. But the obstacles that have kept India from following the same program over the past 30 years remain in place: ineffective governance, insufficient infrastructure, and scanty spending on primary education and health.

A â€œMake in Indiaâ€ program championed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, now in its eighth year, has been slow to take off.

Indiaâ€™s economic story, however it turns out, will not be a repetition of Chinaâ€™s. There are many ways in which India can rise, especially with industrial manufacturing no longer occupying the central role in the world economy that it once did.

Services now make up a huge and exciting part of the Indian economy, augmented by a low-cost digital infrastructure that India developed on its own. Other glimmers are also emerging: Chip makers are looking to India as a high-end substitute for China; online services are allowing millions of young Indians to work abroad without leaving home; and even life in Indiaâ€™s villages is becoming more urbanized by the year.

The only certainty about the new biggest country in the world is that it will be unlike any that came before it.

https://aliabdaal.com/newsletter/ready-for-an-adventure/

Ready for an Adventure?

Hey friends,

Hereâ€™s a quick tip Iâ€™ve been finding super helpful recently â€“ every morning I try to ask myself: whatâ€™s todayâ€™s adventure?

Last Friday for example, I had to work on my book. But I felt pretty disengaged just sitting at home on the couch on my laptop. Then it hit me: Iâ€™ve always wanted to write a book. Shouldnâ€™t I treat this like the adventure it is?

So what does an adventure look like? Definitely not me sitting at home in my pyjamas and dressing gown, hunched over on my laptop. So I left the house, went to a new coffee shop, sat by a sunny window, and made lots of progress on editing the second chapter of the book.

And it felt fun.

So, next time youâ€™re feeling a bit meh about something, take 5 seconds to ask: what would this look like if it was an adventure? That simple reframing could make your whole day more enjoyable.

Have a great week!

Ali xx

https://aliabdaal.com/newsletter/the-secret-to-creativity/

The Secret to Creativity

Hey friends,

Last week I finished the book â€˜Unreasonable Hospitalityâ€™ by Will Guidara. If youâ€™re not familiar with him, Will Guidara is former owner of some of New Yorkâ€™s most expensive restaurants, including one which was recently named the best restaurant in the world.

The bookâ€™s packed full of interesting ideas, but his approach to creativity was something that particularly stood out to me.

Now, Iâ€™ve never really considered myself to be a creative person â€“ Iâ€™ve got friends who can seemingly pull amazing ideas out of thin air, whereas I feel like Iâ€™ve got to rely heavily on external sources of inspiration. Like, when I sit down to come up with ideas for something I usually turn to things Iâ€™ve read, watched, or listened to so I can gradually piece things together and connect the dots in my own way.

Creativity just isnâ€™t a spontaenous process for me, which is how Iâ€™ve always thought it should be.

But, in the book, Will talks about creativity as something thatâ€™s far more systematic than spontaneous. Basically, he says that the people we think are most creative are the ones that have a systematic process behind that creativity.

This was a very liberating idea because Iâ€™ve had this limiting belief for some time that â€˜Iâ€™m not a very creative personâ€™. But, if we think of creativity as being a systematic process, rather than a spontaneous process, then this isnâ€™t true at all.

For example, Iâ€™ve got systematic processes for my creativity when it comes to making YouTube videos (which we teach our students in the Part-Time YouTuber Academy â€“ enrolment closes on Friday 17 March btw ğŸ˜‰) and systematic processes for thinking of business ideas (which involves journalling and asking myself various questions).

And although these processes donâ€™t look that creative, theyâ€™re responsible for the consistent creative output that has helped me to create hundreds of videos and grow a multi-million dollar business over the last few years.

So, the takeaway here is that creativity is an active process.

As William Faulkner once said, â€˜I only write when inspiration strikes. Fortunately it strikes at nine every morning.â€™

The point is, the only way to be properly creative is to show up and put in the work.

So, if youâ€™re ever held back by the limiting belief that â€˜youâ€™re not creative enough to do Xâ€™, realise that the way you become more creative is to stop waiting for inspiration to strike and start taking action.

Have a great week!

Ali xx

https://aliabdaal.com/newsletter/should-you-work-for-free/

Should You Work For Free?

Hey friends,

I interviewed writer extraordinaire Nicolas Cole on my Deep Dive podcast the other day. And we got talking about â€˜the return-on-investment (ROI) on free workâ€™.

See, most people make the mistake of charging too early when theyâ€™re breaking into a new industry (eg as a copywriter or video editor).

That builds a barrier: â€˜you have to pay $X to work with meâ€™. So they end up competing with thousands of other freelancers on Upwork or Fiverr, and 99% of potential clients never see their work.

The smarter alternative is to work for free â€“ but be strategic about it.

Draw up a list of dream collaborators.

Then send out sample blogs, video edits, or pieces of graphic design youâ€™ve made especially for them, for free. Post it on social media as well, saying â€˜check out this cool thing I made for Xâ€™.

If an influential person sees work you did for them and really likes it, I almost guarantee theyâ€™ll offer to pay for more.

If a video editor turned one of my full-length videos into an amazing YouTube Short for free, Iâ€™d throw money at them to produce more.

But most people donâ€™t realise this.

So they send generic emails saying â€˜hi, Iâ€™d like to work with you, my rate is Xâ€™. And these emails get ignored, because I just donâ€™t have the time to get into a long email discussion and look through someoneâ€™s portfolio.

Now, a lot of people say â€˜never, ever work for free, people will take advantage.â€™ And I 100% agree that if a sketchy person asks you to â€˜write a few blog posts for free so I can see how good you areâ€™, you should say â€˜noâ€™.

But if youâ€™re strategic about doing free work (and good at what you do), I promise that the money & collaborations will start flooding in.

Have a great week!

Ali xx

entry.content:
åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼šhttps://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MzA5MjM3NDk5Ng==&mid=2650767689&idx=1&sn=90653d741d85a6633d62fab1a7527dca&chksm=886533f2bf12bae43c8909631ac26d236edb70916e2b36e7d0af59e7b0416da67c6d234e0b04&cur_album_id=1786181186118057992&scene=189#wechat_redirect

Goodbye Covid: tourists mob Chinaâ€™s most popular attractions during Labor Day

From the Great Wall to Shanghaiâ€™s waterfront Bund, Chinaâ€™s most famous destinations are being mobbed during the Labor Day holiday by throngs of domestic tourists who are traveling again in huge numbers after the country ended three years of strict pandemic controls.

More than 240 million holidaymakers are expected to travel within or outside Chinaâ€™s mainland during the five-day break that began on Saturday, state media CCTV reported Monday, an increase of more than 20% from pre-pandemic levels in 2019.

Beijing received nearly 2 million tourists on the first day of the holiday, double the number from last year, according to the Beijing Cultural and Tourism Department.

In Shanghai, over 7 million tourists arrived in the city for the weekend, according to Shanghai Travel Data. Tickets to Shanghai Disneyland have been sold out until May 3, its website showed.

Police in the city of Xiâ€™an, home to the terracotta warriors, have warned tourists to stay away from a busy shopping street sandwiched between two popular heritage sites.

On Saturday, China Railway logged a record 19.7 million railway trips with a predicted figure on Sunday of 18 million trips.

The sheer size of the crowds traveling across the nation has baffled some citizens.

â€œWhy are there so many people? I canâ€™t even get McDonaldâ€™s,â€ one internet user wrote on Chinaâ€™s Twitter-like Weibo.

Also known as the May Day holiday, the Labor Day break is one of three major annual holidays in China. The boom in tourism is likely to boost the Chinese economy.

Growth got off to a solid start in 2023, with the economy expanding by 4.5% in the first quarter, as consumers went on a spending spree that is continuing with the current holiday.

Mysterious cancelations

Chinese travel booking website Trip.com reported domestic bookings alone had risen by 700% compared to last year, when many restaurants and retailers were shut and travel was complicated due to the pandemic.

Accommodation was selling out this year weeks ahead of the holiday, pushing up prices, according to state media.

And there have been complaints of scalping.

Due to the high demand, according to state media, many Chinese tourists who had booked their accommodations early at low prices were later told to cancel their reservations, forcing them to have to book again at higher prices.

A wide range of excuses was given, they reported, with internet users taking to popular Chinese social media sites such as Weibo and Xiaohongshu to complain about their plight.

One user said on Xiaohongshu, an Instagram-like app, that she booked a place in Tianjin, a coastal city in northern China, for 1,777 yuan ($257) for five days.

Not long after she saw online that the price had soared by almost double, she was told by the owner that her booking had been canceled because of a Covid outbreak.

â€œBut later that night, I went on to Meituan to check,â€ she wrote, referring to a online booking platform. â€œThe place is still available.â€

The situation has prompted state media and provincial law enforcement authorities to issue warnings on Weibo, the equivalent of Twitter in China.

â€œThe unscrupulous practice of these bed-and-breakfasts is ugly,â€ said an opinion piece posted on the social media platform by state media Peopleâ€™s Daily.

entry.content:
åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼šhttps://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/0VZ8GDqQvFPHVz3vVirWjQ

Why are nursery rhymes both a blessing for parents and important to children?

As evening sets in and parents put their children to bed, many resort to singing nursery rhymes to lull them off to sleep.

But nursery rhymes are not just a good way of calming your kids, they also teach them a few things.

Dr Georgina Nutton, an early childhood education lecturer at Charles Darwin University (CDU), said nursery rhymes provided children with the building blocks of their first language.

She said the rhyming couplets found in songs like This Old Man, Hey Diddle Diddle and Humpty Dumpty taught children patterns in language that develop as they grow.

â€œWhen they get to about [age] two or three, you will say something and your child will come up with every obscene rhyming word that goes with what youâ€™ve said,â€ Dr Nutton said.

â€œItâ€™s just a playful use of language but it tells us that the child understands those phonemic patterns.â€

â€˜Like filling a piggy bankâ€™

CDU special education lecturer and speech pathologist Dr Bea Staley said nursery rhymes were certainly not integral to a childâ€™s development, but they did help.

â€œYou can get by without them, but why would you?

â€œFrom a language standpoint, little kids are a like a piggy bank and youâ€™ve got to keep putting words in because when they get to school, school is going to start withdrawing that cash.

â€œThe more words theyâ€™ve got at that point, the better they tend to do at school.â€

She said it was the repetitive nature of most nursery rhymes that taught children how sounds and sentences worked.

â€œReally, they are one of the best predictors of future reading proficiency when kids get to school,â€ she said.

â€œAnd when you see that phenomena where kids just magically learn to read, itâ€™s those kids who usually have lots of experience with things like nursery rhymes, rhyme play and sound play.â€

Can I make up my own rhymes?

From a speech pathology point of view, Dr Staley said parents making up their own songs or rhymes had its benefits but they needed to show some caution.

â€œTraditional nursery rhymes already have the rhyme and the cadence, the things that children need,â€ she said.

â€œIf youâ€™re making up your own nursery rhymes you might be undoing some of that, but I still think it would be a good language activity.â€

Dr Nutton said from an early childhood education perspective, growing children needed a growing vocabulary and made-up songs could offer that.

â€œThereâ€™s a lot of fun that you can have making up silly songs and rhyming as your child gets older,â€ she said.

â€œ[But] if youâ€™re enjoying what youâ€™re doing and youâ€™re having fun with it, thatâ€™s what they will learn, rather than the specific content of the rhyme or the song.â€

Any song will do

While rhymes, whether traditional or made up, may be the best for developing language and filling your childâ€™s vocabulary piggy bank, Dr Nutton said there was nothing wrong with simply singing your child to sleep.

â€œI wouldnâ€™t suggest too much heavy metal at bed time, but anything thatâ€™s really familiar to you and has a bit of a rhythm to it can be used.

â€œWhile youâ€™re singing your tone will drop a little and youâ€™ll be using nice rhythmic patterns, but thereâ€™s also a level of how familiar your child is with your particular voice.

â€œFrom before theyâ€™re born theyâ€™re hearing your voice so that creates a sense of security and familiarity.â€

åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼š
https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/102J977_IAgpoF1tX7mTgA

Harvard Study Says Itâ€™s OK to Stay Up Late and Sleep In (so Long as You Do This)

Researchers tracked studentsâ€™ sleeping habits for a month. Hereâ€™s what they found.

Do you believe that the earlier you go to bed and the earlier you get up, the healthier, happier, and more productive youâ€™ll be? Many people do, and many websites, including this one, offer lots of advice about how to be a morning person and why itâ€™s so important to be one.

Well, maybe it isnâ€™t so important after all. A new study from Harvard traced the sleep habits of 61 students over 30 days and correlated those habits with the studentsâ€™ grades. It found that students who got regular sleepâ€“that is, who went to bed and woke up about the same time every dayâ€“did better in school than those who slept irregular hours. You might expect that much to be true, but here are some more surprising findings:

  1. You donâ€™t have to wake up at 5 a.m. after all.

The study did find that students were better off if they slept during â€œnighttimeâ€ hours, but it defined those hours as 10 pm to 10 am. As Charles Czeisler, M.D., chief of the Sleep and Circadian Disorders Division at Brigham and Womenâ€™s Hospital told CNN, â€œThe results of this study are not suggesting everybody has to be a goody-two-shoes. So if you go to bed at 2 and get up at 9, thatâ€™s fine. You just have to consistently do the same thing.â€

  1. Getting enough sleep wonâ€™t help you if you sleep irregular hours.

The researchers expected to find that the irregular sleepers who stayed up till all hours were sleeping fewer hours than their regular-sleeping counterparts. But noâ€“both groups were sleeping about the same number of hours in total because the irregular sleepers were napping during the day. Their grades still suffered, proving what most of us know by instinct: A nap can be nice but itâ€™s no replacement for a good nightâ€™s sleep.

  1. Sleeping irregular hours can make you fat.

Irregular sleepers had delayed circadian rhythms compared to regular sleepers. Both phenomena have been shown to be related to weight gain in earlier studies, the researchers note. If that information isnâ€™t enough to make you stop pulling all-nighters, I donâ€™t know what is.

  1. Irregular sleep could be a symptom of something else.

One thing the study didnâ€™t do is measure the things that might cause someone to become an irregular sleeper, and how they might affect academic performance. For example, if youâ€™re someone who goes to bed at precisely 10 pm every night and wakes up at precisely 5 am every morning, chances are youâ€™re a highly disciplined sort, which means you might also have the discipline to get all your homework done early. Conversely, irregular sleep can be a symptom of depression, and depression could certainly affect oneâ€™s academic performance.

More study is needed to better understand these factors, the researchers say. In the meantime, if youâ€™re a late riser stop beating yourself up about it. Concentrate on getting up at the same late hour every morning instead.

åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼šhttps://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/wSuJJxN934_ukvQ4N-Lj2A

China Box Office: â€˜The First Slam Dunkâ€™ Scores $55 Million in Four-Day Opening Period

The highly-anticipated Japanese animated feature film â€œThe First Slam Dunkâ€ dominated the China cinema box office in its opening weekend. It broke multiple records as it did so.

The film scored $38.5 million (RMB266 million) over the Friday to Sunday weekend, according to data from consultancy Artisan Gateway. However, it opened on Thursday, a day earlier than is the norm in China, and has accumulated $55.2 million over the opening four-day frame.

The film is based on IP that is well-known to a generation of comic book fans and TV audiences in China (early middle-aged men were reported to have been particularly interested) and has already proved a hit in other parts of Asia. (Comscore estimates that the film has grossed $211 million worldwide.)

Approval went wider than a single demographic segment, however. â€œThe First Slam Dunkâ€ received strong acclaim across Chinaâ€™s major movie rating platforms, including a 9.2 out of 10 score from Douban users and 9.4 out of 10 on ticketing platforms Maoyan and Taopiaopiao.

The film played especially well at Imax venues, occupying 731 Imax screens in China. Imax China reported that the film earned RMB38 million ($5.51 million) over four days. That was the biggest opening for any foreign animation title on Imax and for any Japanese film on Imax in China. Imax screens also accounted for 10% of the China box office weekend total.

Artisan Gateway figures show â€œThe First Slam Dunkâ€ enjoyed a nearly 74% share of the total China box office market on a (Friday to Sunday) weekend worth $52.3 million.

The high-scoring newcomer easily edged aside Jackie Chan vehicle â€œRide On,â€ which had led the China box office for the two previous weekends. â€œRide Onâ€ earned $2.9 million over the weekend for a 19-day cumulative of $28.3 million.

â€œHachiko,â€ a Chinese retelling of a Japanese dog-human loyalty tale, earned $2.4 million on its fourth weekend of release. That helped it to a cumulative of $39.4 million since releasing on March 31.

â€œThe Super Mario Bros. Movieâ€ held on to fourth place. It earned $1.8 million in its third weekend frame. While the film powered to an $877 million global cumulative, just $19.4 million of that has come from China.

Fifth place over the weekend was another Japanese animation, â€œSuzume.â€ It earned $1.7 million for a cumulative of $112 million since releasing in China on March 24.

The latest weekend lifted the year-to-date box office total in China to $2.58 billion, according to Artisan Gatewayâ€™s calculation. That is 23% ahead of a COVID-affected 2022 and 15% behind the same point in 2019.

åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼š

https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/8nJyE8dSbOoyPwhDfFnv2g

TikTok Stars Rally in Washington Against Appâ€™s Potential U.S. Ban

TikTok launched a battalion of influencers in the nationâ€™s capital Wednesday to send a message to Congress: Banning the app would be met with widespread popular opposition.

â€œTikTok is not a childrenâ€™s dancing app,â€ said Aidan Kohn-Murphy, a college freshman with close to 300,000 TikTok followers and founder of the advocacy group Gen-Z for Change. â€œIt is one of the most powerful tools that young people have to engage each other and to get civically involved.â€

Mr. Kohn-Murphy was one of more than 20 TikTok personalities with wide followings who traveled to the capital this week at the companyâ€™s invitation to lobby lawmakers and others in advance of TikTok Chief Executive Shou Zi Chewâ€™s appearance before a House committee on Thursday.

The influencersâ€™ blitz is part of TikTokâ€™s response to persistent concerns among U.S. officials.

The Biden administration recently demanded that TikTokâ€™s Chinese owners sell their stakes in the company or face a possible U.S. ban of the app, and members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee are expected to question Mr. Chew about the security concerns and other issues.

TikTok maintains that it isnâ€™t beholden to any government and is a vital platform for 150 million American usersâ€”a theme the influencers worked to underscore in a meeting with journalists near the Capitol on Wednesday.

â€œIt would be difficult to be able to support a candidate that would take away something that is so integral to the direction weâ€™re going as a society,â€ said Baedri Nichole, a bakery owner from Columbus, Ohio, whose â€œhot cocoa bombâ€ confection is a hit on TikTok.

Kenny Jary, an 81-year-old retiree known on TikTok as Patriotic Kenny, said he uses the app to raise money to buy mobility scooters for fellow veterans. Others said the app provided a platform to launch small businesses or discuss topics such as eldercare and mental health.

TikTok covered the groupâ€™s travel and accommodation expenses. The company bused the influencers on Wednesday to the Capitol grounds, where they gathered on a scenic rooftop to shoot their own videos and stand for journalistsâ€™ interviews.

Later in the day, the influencers met with lawmakers and held a news conference near the Capitol building with Rep. Jamaal Bowman (D., N.Y.) and others.

â€œWhy the hysteria and the panic and the targeting of TikTok?â€ asked Mr. Bowman, before suggesting xenophobia against China was at play and Congress should focus instead on addressing broader concerns about social media. â€œAmerican social-media companies have been used to facilitate harms.â€

After threats of banning the app started during the Trump administration, the company has spent recent years building a U.S.-based security apparatus to wall off U.S. user data and give officials the ability to inspect the computer code that recommends videos to users.

TikTok stars were a crucial factor in the companyâ€™s successful effort to fight off a proposed ban during the Trump years. Whether they will have the same influence this time around remains to be seen.

â€œIâ€™m aware of the popularity of the platform. Iâ€™m not oblivious,â€ said Rep. Yvette Clarke (D., N.Y.), a senior member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee who hasnâ€™t yet taken a position on a potential ban. â€œHowever, itâ€™s important to weigh our equities here. National security has to be addressed.â€

Ahead of Mr. Chewâ€™s appearance, TikTok has ramped up lobbying efforts with the help of Oracle Corp., its U.S. data-security partner. Advertisements at the capitalâ€™s Metro subway stops tout the companyâ€™s commitment to user safety.

Mr. Chew also asked the platformâ€™s users to weigh in, in a TikTok post this week disclosing that 150 million Americans are on the app.

â€œSome politicians have started talking about banning TikTok,â€ he said. â€œThis could take TikTok away from all 150 million of you.â€

public class MyOtherThread implements Callable<Integer> {    @Override    public Integer call() throws Exception {        Thread.sleep(1000);        return 2;    }    public static void main(String[] args) throws ExecutionException, InterruptedException {        ExecutorService executor = Executors.newCachedThreadPool();        Future<Integer> result = executor.submit(new MyOtherThread());        // æ³¨æ„get()æ–¹æ³•ä¼šé˜»å¡å½“å‰çº¿ç¨‹        System.out.println(result.get());    }}

public class ObjectLock {// å¯¹è±¡é”    private static Object lock = new Object();    static class ThreadA implements Runnable {        @Override        public void run() {            synchronized (lock) {                for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) {                    System.out.println("Thread A " + i);                }            }        }    }    static class ThreadB implements Runnable {        @Override        public void run() {            synchronized (lock) {                for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) {                    System.out.println("Thread B " + i);                }            }        }    }    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {        new Thread(new ThreadA()).start();// åŒä¸€æ—¶é—´åªèƒ½æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹æŒæœ‰é”ï¼Œç¡çœ æ˜¯è®©Aå…ˆæ‰§è¡Œ        Thread.sleep(10);        new Thread(new ThreadB()).start();    }}

public class WaitAndNotify {// ä½¿ç”¨åŒä¸€ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡é”    private static Object lock = new Object();    static class ThreadA implements Runnable {        @Override        public void run() {            synchronized (lock) {                for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {                    try {                        System.out.println("ThreadA: " + i);// éšæœºå«é†’ç­‰å¾…ä¸­çš„çº¿ç¨‹                        lock.notify();// è¿›å…¥ç­‰å¾…ï¼Œç­‰å¾…å”¤é†’ï¼Œé‡Šæ”¾é”                        lock.wait();                    } catch (InterruptedException e) {                        e.printStackTrace();                    }                }                lock.notify();            }        }    }    static class ThreadB implements Runnable {        @Override        public void run() {            synchronized (lock) {                for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {                    try {                        System.out.println("ThreadB: " + i);                        lock.notify();                        lock.wait();                    } catch (InterruptedException e) {                        e.printStackTrace();                    }                }                lock.notify();            }        }    }    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {        new Thread(new ThreadA()).start();        Thread.sleep(1000);        new Thread(new ThreadB()).start();    }}// è¾“å‡ºï¼šThreadA: 0ThreadB: 0ThreadA: 1ThreadB: 1ThreadA: 2ThreadB: 2ThreadA: 3ThreadB: 3ThreadA: 4ThreadB: 4

public class Signal {// ä¿è¯å¯è§æ€§    private static volatile int signal = 0;    static class ThreadA implements Runnable {        @Override        public void run() {            while (signal < 5) {                if (signal % 2 == 0) {                    System.out.println("threadA: " + signal);                    signal++;                }            }        }    }    static class ThreadB implements Runnable {        @Override        public void run() {            while (signal < 5) {                if (signal % 2 == 1) {                    System.out.println("threadB: " + signal);                    signal = signal + 1;                }            }        }    }    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {        new Thread(new ThreadA()).start();        Thread.sleep(1000);        new Thread(new ThreadB()).start();    }}// è¾“å‡ºï¼šthreadA: 0threadB: 1threadA: 2threadB: 3threadA: 4

public class Pipe {    static class ReaderThread implements Runnable {        private PipedReader reader;        public ReaderThread(PipedReader reader) {            this.reader = reader;        }        @Override        public void run() {            System.out.println("this is reader");            int receive = 0;            try {                while ((receive = reader.read()) != -1) {                    System.out.print((char)receive);                }            } catch (IOException e) {                e.printStackTrace();            }        }    }    static class WriterThread implements Runnable {        private PipedWriter writer;        public WriterThread(PipedWriter writer) {            this.writer = writer;        }        @Override        public void run() {            System.out.println("this is writer");            int receive = 0;            try {                writer.write("test");            } catch (IOException e) {                e.printStackTrace();            } finally {                try {                    writer.close();                } catch (IOException e) {                    e.printStackTrace();                }            }        }    }    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException, InterruptedException {        PipedWriter writer = new PipedWriter();        PipedReader reader = new PipedReader();        writer.connect(reader); // è¿™é‡Œæ³¨æ„ä¸€å®šè¦è¿æ¥ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½é€šä¿¡        new Thread(new ReaderThread(reader)).start();        Thread.sleep(1000);        new Thread(new WriterThread(writer)).start();    }}// è¾“å‡ºï¼šthis is readerthis is writertest

public class Hello {    private static int stackLength = 0;    public static void test() {        // å±€éƒ¨å˜é‡å¤šï¼Œæ ˆå¸§å¢å¤§        long unused1, unused2, unused3, unused4, unused5,                unused6, unused7, unused8, unused9, unused10,                unused11, unused12, unused13, unused14, unused15,                unused16, unused17, unused18, unused19, unused20,                unused21, unused22, unused23, unused24, unused25,                unused26, unused27, unused28, unused29, unused30,                unused31, unused32, unused33, unused34, unused35,                unused36, unused37, unused38, unused39, unused40,                unused41, unused42, unused43, unused44, unused45,                unused46, unused47, unused48, unused49, unused50,                unused51, unused52, unused53, unused54, unused55,                unused56, unused57, unused58, unused59, unused60,                unused61, unused62, unused63, unused64, unused65,                unused66, unused67, unused68, unused69, unused70,                unused71, unused72, unused73, unused74, unused75,                unused76, unused77, unused78, unused79, unused80,                unused81, unused82, unused83, unused84, unused85,                unused86, unused87, unused88, unused89, unused90,                unused91, unused92, unused93, unused94, unused95,                unused96, unused97, unused98, unused99, unused100; public class Hello {    /**     * JDK8å‰VMå‚æ•°ï¼š -XX:PermSize=6M -XX:MaxPermSize=6M     * JDK8VMå‚æ•°ï¼š-XX:MetaspaceSize=6M -XX:MaxMetaspaceSize=6M     */    public static void main(String[] args) {        // ä½¿ç”¨Setä¿æŒå¸¸é‡æ± å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œé¿å…Full GCå›æ”¶å¸¸é‡æ± è¡Œä¸º        Set<String> set = new HashSet<>();        // åœ¨shortèŒƒå›´å†…è¶³ä»¥è®©6Må¤§å°çš„PermSizeï¼ˆæ°¸ä¹…ä»£ï¼ŒJDK8å‰æœ‰ï¼ŒJDK8åŠä¹‹åç‰ˆæœ¬éƒ½å·²é‡‡ç”¨å…ƒç©ºé—´æ›¿ä»£ï¼‰äº§ç”ŸOOMäº†        short i = 0;        // JDK8å‰ï¼ŒæŠ›å‡ºOOMå¼‚å¸¸        // JDK8ä¸‹ï¼Œæ­£å¸¸æƒ…å†µä¼šè¿›å…¥æ­»å¾ªç¯ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ä¼šæŠ›å‡ºä»»ä½•å¼‚å¸¸        while (true) {            // String.intern()è¿›å…¥å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¸¸é‡æ±             set.add(String.valueOf(i++).intern());        }    }}

entry.title: CBAé‡ç£…ç½šå•
entry.content:
åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼š

https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/_nuY7RkNS4C7RICGosHtPw

China basketball teams thrown out after match-fixing claims

Two teams were disqualified from the ongoing Chinese Basketball Association season on Monday after suspicions of match-fixing, with Yao Ming bemoaning a â€œsorrowful weekendâ€.

The Shanghai Sharks overtook the Jiangsu Dragons in the last two minutes of a CBA playoff game on Friday after the Dragons lost possession of the ball multiple times.

The Sharks â€“ where CBA president and NBA all-star Yao began his professional career â€“ won the game 108-104, advancing to the quarter-finals.

The match sparked fury among basketball fans on Chinese social media and allegations of match-fixing. The CBA said on Saturday that it would investigate the game.

The CBA did not use the phrase â€œmatch-fixingâ€ on Monday and instead accused them of â€œpassive playingâ€ during two recent games involving the teams, state broadcaster CCTV reported.

In addition to being disqualified from this season, both teams had their budgets slashed by five million yuan ($730,000).

Their head coaches and general managers have been slapped with suspensions of three to five years, CCTV said.

â€œBoth clubs have a long historyâ€¦ and both teams have produced milestone figures,â€ Yao said in video footage published by the state-run China News Service.

â€œThe more we talk about it, the more pain we feel,â€ said the 42-year-old, who starred for the Houston Rockets in the NBA between 2002 and 2011.

CBA sides Shanghai, Jiangsu disqualified from season due to lack of competitive effort

The Chinese Basketball Association (CBA) has disqualified the Shanghai Sharks and the Jiangsu Dragons from the 2022-2023 CBA season on Monday, citing their lack of competitive effort in the first round of the playoffs.

In a statement, the CBA Disciplinary and Ethics Commission confirmed that Shanghai displayed negative contention in the second game of the series, while Jiangsu demonstrated a lack of competitive effort in the third game, which Shanghai won 108-104 to advance.

The behavior of both teams constituted a grave violation of sportsmanship, leading to their disqualification from the 2022-2023 season and nullification of their results.

Each club received a fine of five million yuan (approximately 727,000 U.S. dollars).

Shanghaiâ€™s coach Li Chunjiang received a five-year ban, while his Jiangsu counterpart, Li Nan, faced a three-year suspension.

Jiangsuâ€™s club general manager Shi Linjie was barred from basketball-related activities for five years, while Jiang Yusheng, general manager of the Shanghai club, faced a three-year restriction from basketball-related activities.

Following Shanghaiâ€™s disqualification, the CBA leagueâ€™s governing body ruled that the Shenzhen Aviators would advance to the final four in the CBA playoffs.

entry.title: BBC:æˆ‘ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆä¸ä¼šçœ‹æŸ¥å°”æ–¯å›½ç‹åŠ å†•å…¸ç¤¼
entry.content:
åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼šhttps://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/zwn4EnJinxGkf_Hlb3VOUQ

Why I wonâ€™t be watching the Kingâ€™s coronation

Millions of people are expected to tune into the coronation of King Charles III on 6 May. While some might revel in the crowds, parties, pomp and ceremony, others will do everything they can to avoid the occasion.

BBC News spoke to four people who will not be watching.

â€˜Itâ€™s a huge waste of public moneyâ€™

Oli in Stroud will not be following the events either.

â€œI think itâ€™s a huge waste of public money,â€ says the 51-year-old midwife.

For Oli, a hereditary head of state is elitist and undemocratic.

â€œYouâ€™ve got this tiny little band of elite at the top of our society that are thriving and then everybody else is scrabbling around trying to make ends meet and put food on the table,â€ she says.

As an NHS worker, she says taxpayersâ€™ money could be better spent.

â€œThe Royal Family have their own personal wealth and yet we, the taxpayers, are having to fund this parade in the middle of a financial crisis,â€ she says.

Instead of watching, she will be on shift at hospital helping to deliver babies.

â€˜Iâ€™d rather have a lie-in and eat some doughnutsâ€™

Tarek Ahmed says he does not â€œcare enough to watch for hoursâ€.

â€œIâ€™d rather have a lie-in and eat some doughnutsâ€, explains the 21-year-old marketing executive from Kent.

Tarek says he has not decided whether or not he supports the Royal Family.

â€œIf they make the country money, happy days. That means more money for things like the NHS and education. But if thatâ€™s not the case then I donâ€™t want them. I donâ€™t know the answer,â€ he says.

A YouGov poll commissioned by the BBCâ€™s Panorama programme suggests broad support for keeping the monarchy, with 58% preferring it to an elected head of state - which was supported by 26%.

Tarek plans to spend Saturday morning watching the new Avatar film with his family instead. But he might catch a quick round-up of the Coronation afterwards.

â€œIâ€™ll probably look at highlights with the moment the crown goes on his head - thatâ€™s a bit of history.â€

Despite his views on the Coronation, Tarek is looking forward to the bank holiday.

â€œWe get an extra day off and the entire country deserves thatâ€, he says.

â€˜I donâ€™t feel like Charles deserves to be Kingâ€™

Joana Firmino says she does not like King Charles and does not want to see him being crowned.

â€œI donâ€™t think heâ€™s going to be a good role model,â€ says the 21-year-old waitress from Kent.

Joana was a fan of Queen Elizabeth II and was â€œextremely upsetâ€ when she passed away.

But she worries King Charles may â€œnot make good decisionsâ€ because of his troubled relationship with his first wife, Diana, Princess of Wales. She says his son Prince William would be â€œa way better kingâ€.

â€œIf it was William being crowned, I would definitely watch. But I donâ€™t want to spend hours watching someone I donâ€™t really like getting crowned as King when I believe he doesnâ€™t deserve to be,â€ she says.

Instead, Joana will be jetting off on holiday to the Philippines.

â€œIâ€™m not going to be wasting my time. Iâ€™ll be enjoying the sunny weather and tropical beaches,â€ she adds.

â€˜Iâ€™ll be busy working on Eurovisionâ€™

Luke Dudley is working as a spotlight operator at the Eurovision Song Contest and says â€œback-to-backâ€ rehearsals means he cannot watch the ceremony.

â€œItâ€™s a very tightly packed schedule which weâ€™ve been religiously sticking to,â€ he explains.

The 27-year-old from Manchester works in the lighting department, providing the key light for artists and presenters on the stage.

Luke is disappointed to be missing â€œa momentous period in our historyâ€.

â€œFriends and family have parties planned, so itâ€™s a massive shame. I love the pomp, ceremony and spectacle of it all,â€ he says.

Despite Luke not being able to participate in the coronation parties, he says he â€œcouldnâ€™t pass on an opportunity like Eurovisionâ€.

â€œI couldnâ€™t be more excited. Thereâ€™s nothing like it.â€

åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼š

https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/wn1098St-eAz1-oSekMExw

Do You Really Need 8 Hours of Sleep Every Night? Body Stuff with Dr. Jen Gunter

From: TED

Sleep is so important.

We need it to live.

And when we canâ€™t sleep, weâ€™re desperate for help.

But lately, our fascination with sleep feels as if itâ€™s taken on an urgency.

Do a quick internet search for sleep and youâ€™ll find a slew of articles about how to make your sleep perfect.

New gadgets, fancy alarm clocks, stay away from blue light.

There are lots of services, products and advice columns that tell us weâ€™re sleeping wrong.

Not enough, not quality sleep, wrong position.

Even worse, you might find scary messaging claiming that if youâ€™re not sleeping right, your life is going to be shorter. Youâ€™re going to get all kinds of diseases.

One of the biggest worries we have about our sleep is that weâ€™re not getting enough and that anything less than seven hours a night means that weâ€™re doomed to bad health, everything from high blood pressure to Alzheimerâ€™s disease.

But there are two flaws with this kind of messaging.

The first flaw is that itâ€™s not completely accurate.

Seven to eight hours of sleep, while recommended for adults, is just an average.

And while messages have to be simplified for health communication to the public, sometimes important nuances get lost.

So yes, itâ€™s true that not getting enough sleep in the long term is associated with health problems like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and depression.

But fixating solely on seven to eight hours ignores the fact that thereâ€™s a range of sleep that people need.

The duration of a good nightâ€™s sleep can be different for different people.

Some adults need eight, but some are just fine on six.

The second flaw with this kind of doomsday messaging is that it can be counterproductive, especially for people who do have trouble sleeping.

For instance, in 2019, it was estimated that 21 percent of adults in the US were wearing sleep tracking devices. And that number is probably growing.

And I get it.

Itâ€™s fascinating to see how much sleep youâ€™ve gotten each night and to know what part of your night was spent in deep sleep or dreaming.

But having all of that sleep data is causing some people to become obsessed with it so much so that itâ€™s leading to a condition some called orthosomnia - a preoccupation with the constant need to achieve perfect sleep.

And this condition, ironically, is causing more sleep problems.

Now orthosomnia might be an extreme example, but the anxiety of not getting enough sleep is keeping some of us up at night.

So hereâ€™s what some experts are saying. Stop fixating on the number because that can lead to unrealistic expectations of sleep.

According to Dr. Colleen Carney, a psychologist and the head of the Ryerson University Sleep Lab, the basic questions you should ask yourself are:

Do I feel reasonably well-rested during the day?

Do I generally sleep through the night without disturbances?

Or, if I wake, do I fall back asleep easily?

Can I stay awake through the day without involuntarily falling asleep?

If your answers are yes to all three, you probably donâ€™t need to worry about your sleep.

And if youâ€™re struggling with your sleep, instead of buying expensive blue light filters or fancy sleep trackers, try talking with your doctor to make sure there arenâ€™t any medical conditions that need to be explored first.

Then try evidence-based recommendations laid out by the American Academy of Sleep Medicine.

Whatâ€™s really cool is that thereâ€™s a highly effective therapy - called cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, or CBT-I. It doesnâ€™t have any medications involved. And it has a really low failure rate.

entry.title: 2023å¹´çš„6ä¸ªäººç”Ÿå»ºè®®
entry.content:
åŸæ–‡åœ°å€ï¼š

https://aliabdaal.com/newsletter/6-life-lessons-for-2023/

6 Life Lessons for 2023

Hey friends,

Itâ€™s that time of year where I sit down, have some tea, and reflect on what Iâ€™ve learned over the past 12 months.

So, here are six key lessons that I want to carry with me into 2023.

ğŸ˜“ 1. Stop Pressing the Try Harder Button

We all fall into the trap of thinking â€œIâ€™ll just try harder next timeâ€ when we fail. But that approach isnâ€™t usually effective.

Instead, itâ€™s better to build a sustainable system for achieving our goals. That way, we wonâ€™t repeatedly fail or push yourself to burnout.

For example, if youâ€™re a YouTuber and struggling to get your weekly video out on time, donâ€™t just plan to work extra hours in the evening. Consider outsourcing your editing, making shorter videos, or replacing one video per month with a simple vlog.

Build a system that works for you.

ğŸ”‹2. Energisers vs Drainers

Next time you have to choose between two options, ask yourself which one will drain you and which one will energise you. Then choose the option thatâ€™ll energise you.

Some examples might include:

  • Time with friends > Netflix
  • Evening gym sesh > morning gym sesh
  • Your dream work > soulless corporate job that pays twice as much.

ğŸ›‹ï¸ 3. Choose to Be Satisfied

Donâ€™t beat yourself up at the end of the day for not getting enough done. You can just choose to be satisfied with what you did.

This might sound a bit wishy-washy, but it genuinely works. You can even say to yourself, Well done [insert name here], you wrote 200 words today. Now itâ€™s time to take a break.

Give yourself permission to switch off and get enough rest so that you can perform properly the next day.

ğŸ“† 4. Planning and Doing Are Different Modes of Being

Planning is fundamentally different to doing, and both require a totally different headspace.

So, plan out what youâ€™re going to do at the start of the day. Then for the rest of the day, simply execute on that plan. Never try to plan and do at the same time.

This is incredibly effective and works on a macro level as well. In 2022, my weeks where I planned everything in advance were much smoother and more productive.

ğŸŒ… 5. Wake Up at the Same Time Every Day

One of the best hacks for improving your sleep quality (and overall quality of life) is to wake up at the same time every day.

Choose a waking time like 7 or 7:30 thatâ€™ll let you get plenty of morning sunlight. Listening to the Huberman Lab episode on sleep and talking to circadian rhythm specialist Russell Foster made me focus a lot more on sleep last year.

Iâ€™ve been more rigorous about waking up at the same time, and feel way better for it.

ğŸ¤”6. The Pain of Rejection is Better than the Pain of Regret

Whatever youâ€™re struggling to do, shoot your shot. Whether itâ€™s asking someone out, starting a business, moving to a new countryâ€¦ 99% of the time, the pain of failure or rejection is 100 times better than living with â€˜what ifâ€™ for the rest of your life.

There have been some bumps along the wayâ€¦ but if I hadnâ€™t studied medicine, started a YouTube channel, or moved to London, I guarantee that Iâ€™d still be thinking about those things today with some mild regret.

So, carpe diem.

Have a great week!

Ali xx

   // åˆå§‹åŒ–å¤±è´¥    if(list->arr == NULL) {        return 0;    }    list->capacity = 5;    list->size = 0;    // æˆåŠŸ    return 1;}/** * é¡ºåºè¡¨æ’å…¥æ“ä½œ * @param list * @param index ä½åºï¼Œæ’å…¥ç¬¬å‡ ä¸ªä½ç½® */_Bool insertList(ArrayList list, int index, int data) {    // indexéæ³•ï¼Œæ’å…¥å¤±è´¥    if(index < 1 || index > list->size + 1) {        return 0;    }    // æ‰©å®¹    if(list->size == list->capacity) {        // åŸæ¥å®¹é‡çš„1.5å€        int newCapacity = list->capacity + (list->capacity >> 1);        // ä½¿ç”¨å‡½æ•°realloc()æ‰©å¤§å†…å­˜        int * newArr = realloc(list->arr, sizeof(int) * newCapacity);        list->arr = newArr;        list->capacity = newCapacity;    }    for (int i = list->size; i > index - 1; i--) {        // ä»æ’å…¥ä½ç½®å¼€å§‹æ‰€æœ‰å…ƒç´ å‘åç§»åŠ¨        list->arr[i] = list->arr[i-1];    }    // æ’å…¥å…ƒç´     list->arr[index - 1] = data;    // è®°å½•å…ƒç´ ä¸ªæ•°    list->size++;    return 1;}/** * é¡ºåºè¡¨åˆ é™¤æ“ä½œ * @param list * @param index ä½åºï¼Œä»1å¼€å§‹ * @return */_Bool deleteList(ArrayList list, int index) {    //éæ³•åˆ é™¤    if(index < 1 || index > list->size) {        return 0;    }    // ä»åˆ é™¤ä½ç½®å¼€å§‹ï¼Œåé¢çš„å¾€å‰ç§»åŠ¨    for (int i = index - 1; i < list->size; ++i) {        list->arr[i] = list->arr[i+1];    }    // é•¿åº¦å‡å°    list->size--;    return 1;}/** * é€šè¿‡ä½åºæŸ¥æ‰¾å…ƒç´  * @param list * @param index ä½åºï¼Œä»1å¼€å§‹ * @return è¿”å›æŸ¥æ‰¾çš„å…ƒç´  */int getDataByIndex(ArrayList list, int index) {    // éæ³•ä½åº    if(index < 1 || index > list->size) {        return INT_MAX;    }    int data = list->arr[index - 1];    return data;}/** * é¡ºåºè¡¨å½“å‰é•¿åº¦ * @param list * @return è¿”å›é•¿åº¦å¤§å° */int getListLength(ArrayList list) {    return list->size;}/** * æ‰“å°æ•°æ® * @param list */void printList(ArrayList list) {    for (int i = 0; i < list->size; ++i) {        printf("%d", list->arr[i]);        printf("\t");    }}int main() {    // åˆ›å»ºæ–°çš„ç»“æ„ä½“å˜é‡ï¼ˆä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆä¸å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥ArrayList listå‘¢ï¼Ÿï¼‰    struct List list;    printf("å¼€å§‹åˆå§‹åŒ–\n");    if(initList(&list)) {        insertList(&list, 1, 20);        insertList(&list, 1, 30);        insertList(&list, 1, 50);        insertList(&list, 1, 60);        insertList(&list, 1, 70);        insertList(&list, 1, 80);        deleteList(&list, 6);        printList(&list);        printf("å½“å‰é•¿åº¦ï¼š%d\n", getListLength(&list));        printf("å½“å‰æŸ¥æ‰¾å…ƒç´ ä¸ºï¼š%d", getDataByIndex(&list, 1));    } else {        printf("åˆå§‹åŒ–å¤±è´¥");    }}

#include <stdio.h>#include <stdlib.h>// é“¾è¡¨çš„ç»“æ„ä½“typedef struct LinkNode{    int data;    struct LinkNode * next;} * LinkList;/** * åˆå§‹åŒ–é“¾è¡¨ï¼ˆå¸¦å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼‰ * @param lNode */void initLinkNode(LinkList lNode) {    // å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹é»˜è®¤æŒ‡å‘NULL, å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸å­˜å‚¨æ•°æ®    struct LinkNode * head = lNode;    head->next = NULL;}/** * é“¾è¡¨æ’å…¥æ“ä½œ * @param head å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹æŒ‡é’ˆ * @param index ä½åºï¼ˆä»1å¼€å§‹ï¼‰ * @param data æ’å…¥çš„æ•°æ® * @return 0è¡¨ç¤ºå¤±è´¥ï¼Œ1è¡¨ç¤ºæˆåŠŸ */_Bool insertNode(LinkList head, int index, int data) {    // éæ³•ä½åº    if(index < 1) {        return 0;    }    struct LinkNode * p = head;    // --index å…ˆå‡ç„¶åå†æ“ä½œ    while(--index) {        // å½“indexä¸º0æ—¶ï¼ŒpæŒ‡å‘çš„æ°å¥½æ˜¯æ’å…¥ä½ç½®çš„å‰ä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹        p = p->next;        // indexè¶Šç•Œ        if(p == NULL) {            return 0;        }    }    // ä¸ºæ’å…¥çš„æ–°èŠ‚ç‚¹åˆ†é…å†…å­˜    LinkList newNode = malloc(sizeof(LinkList));    newNode->data = data;    newNode->next = p->next;    p->next = newNode;    return 1;}/** * é“¾è¡¨åˆ é™¤æ“ä½œ * @param head å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹æŒ‡é’ˆ * @param index ä½åºï¼ˆä»1å¼€å§‹ï¼‰ * @return */_Bool deleteNode(LinkList head, int index) {    //éæ³•ä½åº    if(index < 1) {        return 0;    }    LinkList p = head;    // åªæœ‰å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æ—¶å€™    if(p->next == NULL) {        return 0;    }    while(--index){        p = p->next;        // indexè¶Šç•Œ        if(p == NULL) {            return 0;        }    }    // è®°å½•è¦åˆ é™¤çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹åå†åˆ é™¤    struct LinkNode * q = p->next;    p->next = q->next;    // é‡Šæ”¾å†…å­˜    free(q);    return 1;}/** * æ ¹æ®ä½åºæŸ¥æ‰¾å…ƒç´  */int findNodeData(LinkList head, int index) {    //éæ³•ä½åº    if(index < 1) {        return 0;    }    LinkList p = head;    if(p->next == NULL) {        return INT_MAX;    }    while (--index) {        p = p->next;        if(p == NULL) {            return INT_MAX;        }    }    return p->next->data;}/** * è®¡ç®—é“¾è¡¨é•¿åº¦ï¼ˆé™¤å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼‰ */int getLinkListLength(LinkList head) {    int size = 0;    while (head->next) {        head = head->next;        size++;    }    return size;}/** * æ‰“å°æ•°æ® */void printLinkList(LinkList linkList) {    while (linkList) {        linkList = linkList->next;        printf("%d\t", linkList->data);    }}int main() {    struct LinkNode head;    initLinkNode(&head);    insertNode(&head, 1, 10);    insertNode(&head, 1, 20);    insertNode(&head, 3, 30);    deleteNode(&head, 1);    printf("%d\n", findNodeData(&head, 2));    printf("%d\n", getLinkListLength(&head));    printLinkList(&head);}

åŒå‘é“¾è¡¨

#include <stdio.h>#include <stdlib.h>// åŒå‘é“¾è¡¨çš„ç»“æ„ä½“typedef struct DoubleLinkNode{    int data;    // æŒ‡å‘ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ª    struct DoubleLinkNode * next;    // æŒ‡å‘ä¸Šä¸€ä¸ª    struct DoubleLinkNode * prev;} * DoubleLinkList;/** * åˆå§‹åŒ–åŒå‘é“¾è¡¨ * @param head */void initLinkNode(DoubleLinkList head) {    // å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹é»˜è®¤æŒ‡å‘NULL, å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸å­˜å‚¨æ•°æ®    head->next = NULL;    head->prev = NULL;}/** * åŒå‘é“¾è¡¨æ’å…¥æ“ä½œ * @param head å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹æŒ‡é’ˆ * @param index ä½åºï¼ˆä»1å¼€å§‹ï¼‰ * @param data æ’å…¥çš„æ•°æ® * @return 0è¡¨ç¤ºå¤±è´¥ï¼Œ1è¡¨ç¤ºæˆåŠŸ */_Bool insertNode(DoubleLinkList head, int index, int data) {    // éæ³•ä½åº    if(index < 1) {        return 0;    }    struct DoubleLinkNode * p = head;    // --index å…ˆå‡ç„¶åå†æ“ä½œ    while(--index) {        // å½“indexä¸º0æ—¶ï¼ŒpæŒ‡å‘çš„æ°å¥½æ˜¯æ’å…¥ä½ç½®çš„å‰ä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹        p = p->next;        // indexè¶Šç•Œ        if(p == NULL) {            return 0;        }    }    // ä¸ºæ’å…¥çš„æ–°èŠ‚ç‚¹åˆ†é…å†…å­˜    DoubleLinkList newNode = malloc(sizeof(DoubleLinkList));    // å†…å­˜åˆ†é…å¤±è´¥    if(newNode == NULL) {        return 0;    }    newNode->data = data;    // åç»§èŠ‚ç‚¹å¯èƒ½ä¸å­˜åœ¨    if(p->next) {        newNode->next = p->next;        // ä¸åˆ¤æ–­ï¼Œæ­¤å¤„å¯èƒ½ä¼šç©ºæŒ‡é’ˆå¼‚å¸¸        p->next->prev = newNode;    } else {        newNode->next = NULL;    }    p->next = newNode;    newNode->prev = p;    return 1;}/** * åŒå‘é“¾è¡¨åˆ é™¤æ“ä½œ * @param head å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹æŒ‡é’ˆ * @param index ä½åºï¼ˆä»1å¼€å§‹ï¼‰ * @return */_Bool deleteNode(DoubleLinkList head, int index) {    //éæ³•ä½åº    if(index < 1) {        return 0;    }    DoubleLinkList p = head;    // åªæœ‰å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æ—¶å€™    if(p->next == NULL) {        return 0;    }    while(--index){        p = p->next;        // indexè¶Šç•Œ        if(p == NULL) {            return 0;        }    }    // è®°å½•è¦åˆ é™¤çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹åå†åˆ é™¤    struct DoubleLinkNode * q = p->next;    if(q->next) {        p->next = q->next;        q->next->prev = p;    } else { // åˆ é™¤æœ€åä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹        p->next = NULL;    }    // é‡Šæ”¾å†…å­˜    free(q);    return 1;}/** * æ ¹æ®ä½åºæŸ¥æ‰¾å…ƒç´  */int findNodeData(DoubleLinkList head, int index) {    //éæ³•ä½åº    if(index < 1) {        return 0;    }    DoubleLinkList p = head;    if(p->next == NULL) {        return INT_MAX;    }    while (--index) {        p = p->next;        if(p == NULL) {            return INT_MAX;        }    }    return p->next->data;}/** * è®¡ç®—é“¾è¡¨é•¿åº¦ï¼ˆé™¤å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼‰ */int getDoubleLinkListLength(DoubleLinkList head) {    int size = 0;    while (head->next) {        head = head->next;        size++;    }    return size;}

å®ç°ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨

#include <stdio.h>#include <stdlib.h>#define SIZE 9// å°†æ•°ç»„å…ƒç´ å°è£…æˆ keytypedef struct Element{    int key;}* Element;// åˆ©ç”¨æ•°ç»„å®ç°å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨typedef struct HashTable{    Element* table;}* HashTable;/** * å“ˆå¸Œå‡½æ•°ï¼Œè®¡ç®—å¯¹åº”çš„å“ˆå¸Œå€¼ */int hash(int key) {    return key % SIZE;}// åˆå§‹åŒ–å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨void init(HashTable hashTable) {    hashTable->table = malloc(sizeof (struct Element) * SIZE);    for(int i = 0; i < SIZE; i++) {        hashTable->table[i] = NULL;    }}// å¾€å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨ä¸­æ’å…¥å…ƒç´ ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„æš‚æœªè€ƒè™‘è£…æ»¡çš„æƒ…å†µï¼‰void put(HashTable hashTable, Element element) {    // è®¡ç®—å“ˆå¸Œå€¼    int hashCode = hash(element->key);    // å¯¹å·å…¥åº§    hashTable->table[hashCode] = element;}// æŸ¥æ‰¾int get(HashTable hashTable, int key) {    int hashCode = hash(key);    if(hashTable->table[hashCode]->key == key) {        return 1;    }    return 0;}// åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæ–°å…ƒç´ struct Element* createElement(int key) {    struct Element* element = malloc(sizeof(struct Element));    element->key = key;    return element;}

å†²çªå¤„ç†

çº¿æ€§æ¢æµ‹æ³•

å½“å‰æœ‰å†²çªå°±å¾€åæŸ¥æ‰¾ç©ºé—²ä½ç½®

#include <stdio.h>#include <stdlib.h>#define SIZE 9// å°†æ•°ç»„å…ƒç´ å°è£…æˆ keytypedef struct Element{    int key;}* Element;// åˆ©ç”¨æ•°ç»„å®ç°å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨typedef struct HashTable{    // æ­¤å¤„æ˜¯æŒ‡é’ˆçš„æŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œæ•°ç»„ä¸­å­˜æ”¾çš„æ˜¯åœ°å€    Element* table;}* HashTable;/** * å“ˆå¸Œå‡½æ•°ï¼Œè®¡ç®—å¯¹åº”çš„å“ˆå¸Œå€¼ */int hash(int key) {    return key % SIZE;}// åˆå§‹åŒ–å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨void init(HashTable hashTable) {    hashTable->table = malloc(sizeof (struct Element) * SIZE);    for(int i = 0; i < SIZE; i++) {        hashTable->table[i] = NULL;    }}// å¾€å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨ä¸­æ’å…¥å…ƒç´ ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„æš‚æœªè€ƒè™‘è£…æ»¡çš„æƒ…å†µï¼‰void put(HashTable hashTable, Element element) {    // è®¡ç®—å“ˆå¸Œå€¼    int hashCode = hash(element->key);    int count = 0;    // è‹¥å½“å‰å“ˆå¸Œå€¼å¯¹åº”ä½ç½®å·²æœ‰å…ƒç´ åˆ™å‘åå¯»æ‰¾    while(hashTable->table[hashCode]) {        // é‡æ–°è®¡ç®—å“ˆå¸Œå€¼ï¼Œä¸èƒ½å•çº¯ hashCode++ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å¾ˆå¯èƒ½ä¼šæ•°ç»„ä¸‹æ ‡è¶Šç•Œ        hashCode = hash(element->key + ++count);    }    // å¯¹å·å…¥åº§    hashTable->table[hashCode] = element;}// æŸ¥æ‰¾int get(HashTable hashTable, int key) {    int hashCode = hash(key);    int count = 0;    // è®°å½•æœ€åˆçš„ä½ç½®ï¼Œç›®çš„æ˜¯æ–¹ä¾¿åé¢åˆ¤æ–­ hashcode æ˜¯å¦å·²ç»èµ°äº†ä¸€åœˆå›æ¥    int startIndex = hashCode;    do{        int cur = hashTable->table[hashCode]->key;        if(cur == key) {            return 1;        }        // æ²¡æ‰¾åˆ°åˆ™é‡æ–°è®¡ç®—å“ˆå¸Œå€¼        hashCode = hash(key + ++count);    } while (startIndex != hashCode && hashTable->table[hashCode]);    return 0;}// åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæ–°å…ƒç´ struct Element* createElement(int key) {    struct Element* element = malloc(sizeof(struct Element));    element->key = key;    return element;}int main() {    struct HashTable hashTable;    init(&hashTable);    for (int i = 0; i < 9; ++i) {        put(&hashTable, createElement(i * 9));    }    for (int i = 0; i < 9; ++i) {        printf("%d ", hashTable.table[i]->key);    }}

é“¾åœ°å€æ³•

å½“å‰æœ‰å†²çªåˆ™å°†å…¶å˜æˆé“¾è¡¨è¿æ¥èµ·æ¥

#include <stdio.h>#include <stdlib.h>#define SIZE 9// é“¾è¡¨ç»“æ„typedef struct LinkNode {    int key;    struct LinkNode* next;}* LinkNode;// æ•°ç»„æ¨¡æ‹Ÿå“ˆå¸Œè¡¨typedef struct HashTable {    // æ­¤å¤„æ•°ç»„å­˜æ”¾çš„æ˜¯struct LinkNodeç±»å‹èŠ‚ç‚¹    struct LinkNode* node;}* HashTable;int hash(int key) {    return key % SIZE;}void init(HashTable hashTable) {    hashTable->node = malloc(sizeof(struct LinkNode) * SIZE);    // å°†å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹åˆå§‹åŒ–    for (int i = 0; i < SIZE; ++i) {        // hashtable->node[i] æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯æ•°ç»„ä¸­ç¬¬ i ä¸ªçš„ struct LinkNode èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯æŒ‡é’ˆï¼ˆåœ°å€ï¼‰ï¼Œæ•…åé¢æ˜¯ç”¨ . æ¥å¼•å‡ºå…¶ç»“æ„ä½“å˜é‡        hashTable->node[i].key = -1;        hashTable->node[i].next = NULL;    }}LinkNode createNode(int key) {    LinkNode node = malloc(sizeof(struct LinkNode));    node->key = key;    node->next = NULL;    return node;}void put(HashTable hashTable, int key) {    int hashCode = hash(key);    LinkNode head = &hashTable->node[hashCode];    // è‹¥å·²æœ‰å…ƒç´ å é¢†è¯¥ä½ç½®ï¼Œåˆ™ç»§ç»­ç›´è‡³é“¾è¡¨å°¾ï¼Œç„¶åæ’å…¥    while(head->next) {        head = head->next;    }    head->next = createNode(key);}int get(HashTable hashTable, int key) {    int hashCode = hash(key);    LinkNode head = &hashTable->node[hashCode];    // æ­¤å¤„è®¾è®¡çš„å“ˆå¸Œè¡¨ä¸­çš„é“¾è¡¨å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹é»˜è®¤å…¨ä¸º -1ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼äºè™šæ‹Ÿå¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼‰ï¼Œæ•…çœŸæ­£çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹åœ¨head->nextä¸Š    while(head->next) {        if(head->next->key == key) {            return 1;        }        head = head->next;    }    return 0;}int main() {    struct HashTable table;    init(&table);    put(&table, 10);    put(&table, 19);    put(&table, 20);    printf("%d\n", get(&table, 20));    printf("%d\n", get(&table, 17));    printf("%d\n", get(&table, 19));}

ä½¿ç”¨æ•°æ®å¤„ç†å‡½æ•°

å¸¸ç”¨æ–‡æœ¬å¤„ç†å‡½æ•°

left() # æˆªå–å¹¶è¿”å›å·¦è¾¹çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²right() # æˆªå–å¹¶è¿”å›å³è¾¹çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²concat() # æ‹¼æ¥å­—æ®µlength() # è¿”å›ä¼ çš„é•¿åº¦locate() # æ‰¾å‡ºä¸²çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­—ä¸²lower() # è½¬å°å†™upper() # è½¬å¤§å†™ltrim() # å»é™¤å·¦ç©ºæ ¼rtrim() # å»é™¤å³ç©ºæ ¼substring() # è¿”å›å­—ä¸²çš„å­—ç¬¦soundex() # è¿”å›ä¸²çš„soundexå€¼(å¯¹ä¸²çš„å‘éŸ³ç›¸ä¼¼æ¯”è¾ƒ)

æ—¥æœŸå’Œæ—¶é—´å¤„ç†å‡½æ•°

addDate() # å¢åŠ ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¥æœŸï¼ˆå¤©ï¼Œå‘¨ç­‰ï¼‰addTime() # å¢åŠ ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¶é—´ï¼ˆæ—¶ï¼Œåˆ†ç­‰ï¼‰curDate() # è¿”å›å½“å‰æ—¥æœŸcurTime() # è¿”å›å½“å‰æ—¶é—´Now() # è¿”å›å½“å‰æ—¥æœŸå’Œæ—¶é—´Date() # è¿”å›æ—¥æœŸæ—¶é—´ä¸­çš„æ—¥æœŸéƒ¨åˆ†Time() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¥æœŸæ—¶é—´çš„æ—¶é—´éƒ¨åˆ†DateDiff() # è®¡ç®—ä¸¤ä¸ªæ—¥æœŸä¹‹é—´çš„å·®Date_Add() # é«˜åº¦çµæ´»çš„æ—¥æœŸè¿ç®—å‡½æ•°Date_Format() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ ¼å¼åŒ–çš„æ—¥æœŸæˆ–æ—¶é—´ä¸²DayOfWeek() # å¯¹äºä¸€ä¸ªæ—¥æœŸï¼Œè¿”å›å¯¹åº”çš„æ˜ŸæœŸå‡ Hour() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¶é—´çš„å°æ—¶éƒ¨åˆ†Minute() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¶é—´çš„åˆ†é’Ÿéƒ¨åˆ†Second() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¶é—´çš„ç§’éƒ¨åˆ†Year() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¥æœŸçš„å¹´ä»½éƒ¨åˆ†Month() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¥æœŸçš„æœˆä»½éƒ¨åˆ†Day() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ—¥æœŸçš„å¤©æ•°éƒ¨åˆ†

æ•°å€¼å¤„ç†å‡½æ•°

Abs() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°çš„ç»å¯¹å€¼Cos() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªè§’åº¦çš„ä½™å¼¦Exp() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°çš„æŒ‡æ•°å€¼Mod() # è¿”å›é™¤æ“ä½œçš„ä½™æ•°Pi() # è¿”å›åœ†å‘¨ç‡Rand() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªéšæœºæ•°Sin() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªè§’åº¦çš„æ­£å¼¦Sqrt() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°çš„å¹³æ–¹æ ¹Tan() # è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªè§’åº¦çš„æ­£åˆ‡

AVG() # è¿”å›æŸåˆ—çš„å¹³å‡å€¼(å¿½ç•¥åˆ—å€¼ä¸ºNULLçš„è¡Œ)COUNT() # è¿”å›æŸåˆ—çš„è¡Œæ•°# (1.ä½¿ç”¨COUNT(*)å¯¹è¡¨ä¸­è¡Œçš„æ•°ç›®è¿›è¡Œè®¡æ•°ï¼Œä¸ç®¡è¡¨åˆ—ä¸­åŒ…å«çš„æ˜¯ç©ºå€¼ï¼ˆNULLï¼‰è¿˜æ˜¯éç©ºå€¼ã€‚2.ä½¿ç”¨COUNT(column)å¯¹ç‰¹å®šåˆ—ä¸­å…·æœ‰å€¼çš„è¡Œè¿›è¡Œè®¡æ•°ï¼Œå¿½ç•¥NULLå€¼ã€‚)MAX() # è¿”å›æŸåˆ—çš„æœ€å¤§å€¼(å¿½ç•¥åˆ—å€¼ä¸ºNULLçš„è¡Œ)MIN() # è¿”å›æŸåˆ—çš„æœ€å°å€¼(å¿½ç•¥åˆ—å€¼ä¸ºNULLçš„è¡Œ)SUM() # è¿”å›æŸåˆ—å€¼ä¹‹å’Œ(å¿½ç•¥åˆ—å€¼ä¸ºNULLçš„è¡Œ)

ç»„åˆèšé›†å‡½æ•°

åˆ†ç»„æ•°æ®

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode* removeElements(struct ListNode* head, int val){    struct ListNode* temp;    // å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹å•ç‹¬å¤„ç†    while(head != NULL && head->val == val) {        temp = head;        head = head->next;        free(temp);    }    // ä¸­é—´èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„å¤„ç†    struct ListNode* currentNode = head;    struct ListNode* prev = NULL;    while(currentNode != NULL) {        if(currentNode->val == val) {            prev->next = currentNode->next;            struct ListNode* deleteNode = currentNode;            currentNode = currentNode->next;            free(deleteNode);        } else {            prev = currentNode;            currentNode = currentNode->next;        }    }        return head;}

æ–¹æ³•äºŒï¼šåˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªè™šæ‹Ÿå¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œè¿™æ ·æ‰€æœ‰èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„å¤„ç†éƒ½å¯ä»¥åƒä¸­é—´èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œè€Œæ— éœ€å¯¹å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹è¿›è¡Œå•ç‹¬çš„å¤„ç†äº†

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode* removeElements(struct ListNode* head, int val){    // èµ·åˆ«å    typedef struct ListNode ListNode;    // å»ºç«‹è™šæ‹Ÿå¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹    ListNode* tempHead = (ListNode*) malloc(sizeof(ListNode));    tempHead->next = head;    // éå†æŒ‡é’ˆ    struct ListNode* cur = tempHead;        // åƒå¤„ç†ä¸­é—´èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œç»Ÿä¸€æ“ä½œ    while(cur->next) {         if(cur->next->val == val) {            struct ListNode* temp = cur->next;            cur->next = cur->next->next;            free(temp);        } else {            cur = cur->next;        }    }    // æœ€åè®°å¾—è¿”å›çœŸæ­£çš„å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹    head = tempHead->next;    return head;}

è®¾è®¡é“¾è¡¨

typedef struct MyLinkedList{    int val;    struct MyLinkedList* next;} MyLinkedList;// é¢˜ä¸­ç»™å‡ºçš„æ˜¯è™šæ‹Ÿå¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„è§£æ³•ï¼Œä¼šç®€å•å¾ˆå¤šMyLinkedList* myLinkedListCreate() {    MyLinkedList* head = (MyLinkedList*)malloc(sizeof(MyLinkedList));    head->next = NULL;    return head;}int myLinkedListGet(MyLinkedList* obj, int index) {    if(obj == NULL) {        return -1;    }    int count = -1;    while(obj->next) {        obj = obj->next;        count++;        if(count == index) {            return obj->val;        }    }    return -1;}void myLinkedListAddAtHead(MyLinkedList* obj, int val) {    if(obj) {        MyLinkedList* newNode = (MyLinkedList*)malloc(sizeof(MyLinkedList));        newNode->val = val;        newNode->next = obj->next;        obj->next = newNode;    }}void myLinkedListAddAtTail(MyLinkedList* obj, int val) {    while(obj->next) {        obj = obj->next;    }    MyLinkedList* newNode = (MyLinkedList*)malloc(sizeof(MyLinkedList));    newNode->val = val;    obj->next = newNode;    newNode->next = NULL;}void myLinkedListAddAtIndex(MyLinkedList* obj, int index, int val) {    int count = -1;    MyLinkedList* newNode = (MyLinkedList*)malloc(sizeof(MyLinkedList));    newNode->val = val;    // å¤´æ’    if(index < 0) {        newNode->next = obj->next;        obj->next = newNode;        return;    }    // ä¸­é—´æ­£å¸¸ä½ç½®æ’å…¥    while(obj->next) {        MyLinkedList* prev = obj;        obj = obj->next;        count++;        if(count == index) {            newNode->next = obj;            prev->next = newNode;            return;        }    }    // å°¾æ’    if(obj->next == NULL && count+1 == index) {        obj->next = newNode;        newNode->next = NULL;    }}void myLinkedListDeleteAtIndex(MyLinkedList* obj, int index) {    if(index < 0) {        return;    }    int count = -1;    while(obj->next) {        MyLinkedList* prev = obj;        obj = obj->next;        count++;        if(count == index) {            MyLinkedList* temp = obj;            prev->next = obj->next;            free(temp);            return;        }    }}void myLinkedListFree(MyLinkedList* obj) {    while(obj) {        MyLinkedList* prev = obj;        obj = obj->next;        free(prev);    }}/** * Your MyLinkedList struct will be instantiated and called as such: * MyLinkedList* obj = myLinkedListCreate(); * int param_1 = myLinkedListGet(obj, index);  * myLinkedListAddAtHead(obj, val);  * myLinkedListAddAtTail(obj, val);  * myLinkedListAddAtIndex(obj, index, val);  * myLinkedListDeleteAtIndex(obj, index);  * myLinkedListFree(obj);*/

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode* reverseList(struct ListNode* head){    struct ListNode* prev = NULL;     // ä¸´æ—¶ä¿å­˜    struct ListNode* temp;    struct ListNode* cur = head;    while(cur) {        // ä¿å­˜å¥½æ–¹ä¾¿æ›´æ–°cur        temp = cur->next;        // å¼€å§‹åè½¬        cur->next = prev;        // æ›´æ–°æŒ‡é’ˆ        prev = cur;        cur = temp;    }    return prev;}

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode* swapPairs(struct ListNode* head){    typedef struct ListNode ListNode;    if(head == NULL) {        return head;    }    // è™šæ‹Ÿå¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹    ListNode* tempNode = (ListNode*)malloc(sizeof(ListNode));    tempNode->next = head;    struct ListNode* first = tempNode;    struct ListNode* second, * third;        while(first && first->next && first->next->next) {        second = first->next;        third = first->next->next;        // å¼€å§‹äº¤æ¢        first->next = third;        second->next = third->next;        third->next = second;        // å‘åç§»åŠ¨        first = first->next->next;    }    return tempNode->next;}

æ–¹æ³•ä¸€ï¼šå°†å€’æ•°è½¬æˆé¡ºæ•°ã€‚å…ˆéå†ä¸€æ¬¡é“¾è¡¨æ‰¾åˆ°é“¾è¡¨çš„é•¿åº¦ lenï¼Œç„¶åå¯ä»¥å‘ç°ï¼Œå€’æ•°ç¬¬ n ä¸ªæ°å¥½æ˜¯é¡ºæ•°çš„ len - n + 1 ä¸ªï¼Œç„¶åå†éå†æ‰§è¡Œåˆ é™¤æ“ä½œå³å¯

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode* removeNthFromEnd(struct ListNode* head, int n){    typedef struct ListNode ListNode;    ListNode* tempHead = (ListNode*)malloc(sizeof(ListNode));    tempHead->next = head;    int len = 0;    ListNode* cur = tempHead;    while(cur->next) {        cur = cur->next;        len++;    }    cur = tempHead;    int index = len - n + 1;    int count = 0;    ListNode* prev;    while(cur->next) {        prev = cur;        cur = cur->next;        count++;        if(count == index) {            prev->next = cur->next;            free(cur);            break;        }    }    return tempHead->next;}

æ–¹æ³•äºŒï¼šï¼ˆä¸€æ¬¡éå†å®Œæˆæ‰€æœ‰æ“ä½œï¼‰åŒæŒ‡é’ˆæ“ä½œã€‚å®šä¹‰fastå’ŒslowæŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œè®© fast æŒ‡é’ˆå…ˆèµ°ï¼Œå½“ fast æŒ‡å‘ä¸ slow æŒ‡å‘ä¸­é—´ç›¸éš” n ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹æ—¶ï¼Œä¸¤æŒ‡é’ˆå†åŒæ—¶ç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œç›´åˆ° fast æŒ‡é’ˆæŒ‡å‘ NULL æ—¶ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶ slow æŒ‡é’ˆæŒ‡å‘çš„ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹å³éœ€è¦åˆ é™¤çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode* removeNthFromEnd(struct ListNode* head, int n){    typedef struct ListNode ListNode;    ListNode* tempHead = (ListNode*)malloc(sizeof(ListNode));    tempHead->next = head;        ListNode* fast = head;    ListNode* slow = tempHead;    // å…ˆè®©å¿«æŒ‡é’ˆèµ°ï¼Œç­‰ä¸­é—´ç›¸éš” n ä¸ªå…ƒç´ åï¼Œå¿«æ…¢æŒ‡é’ˆåŒæ—¶èµ°    while(n-- && fast != NULL) {        fast = fast->next;    }    while(fast) {        slow = slow->next;        fast = fast->next;    }    // å¿«æŒ‡é’ˆæŒ‡å‘ä¸º NULL çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œ æ…¢æŒ‡é’ˆæŒ‡å‘çš„ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹å°±æ˜¯éœ€è¦åˆ é™¤çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹    ListNode* temp = slow->next;    slow->next = slow->next->next;    free(temp);    return tempHead->next;}

é“¾è¡¨ç›¸äº¤

ä¸æŸå¹´408çš„çœŸé¢˜ç›¸ç±»ä¼¼ï¼ŒåŒæŒ‡é’ˆæ³•ã€‚å…³é”®åœ¨äºå…ˆè·å–ä¸¤ä¸ªé“¾è¡¨ä¹‹é—´çš„é•¿åº¦å·®ï¼Œç„¶ååˆ¤æ–­é•¿åº¦ï¼Œè®©é•¿çš„å…ˆç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œç­‰åˆ°ä¸¤è€…åœ¨åŒä¸€èµ·è·‘çº¿ååŒæ—¶ç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œå½“ä¸¤æŒ‡é’ˆä½ç½®ç›¸åŒçš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯äº¤æ±‡ç‚¹ï¼Œå¦åˆ™å°±æ²¡æœ‰äº¤æ±‡ç‚¹ã€‚

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode *getIntersectionNode(struct ListNode *headA, struct ListNode *headB) {    typedef struct ListNode ListNode;    int len_A = 0;    int len_B = 0;    // æŒ‡å‘A    ListNode* p = headA;    // æŒ‡å‘B    ListNode* q = headB;    // è·å– A é•¿åº¦    while(p) {        len_A++;        p = p->next;    }     // è·å– B é•¿åº¦    while(q) {        len_B++;        q = q->next;    }    // é•¿åº¦å·®    int substract = len_A > len_B ? len_A - len_B : len_B - len_A;    // æ›´æ–°å›æ¥ï¼Œå¼€å§‹å‡†å¤‡å·¥ä½œ    p = headA;    q = headB;        // é•¿çš„å…ˆç§»åŠ¨    while(substract-- && p && q) {        if(len_A > len_B) {            p = p->next;        } else if(len_A < len_B){            q = q->next;        }    }    // æ­¤æ—¶åŒä¸€èµ·è·‘ä½ç½®    while(p && q) {        if(p == q) {            return q;        }        p = p->next;        q = q->next;    }    return NULL;}

  2. å†åˆ¤æ–­åˆå§‹ç¯å…¥å£ï¼šfast å›åˆ°å¤´èŠ‚ç‚¹é‡æ–°å‡ºå‘ï¼Œslowç»§ç»­åœ¨åŸä½ç½®ç»§ç»­å‡ºå‘ï¼Œå½“ä¸¤è€…å†æ¬¡ç›¸é‡æ—¶å°±æ˜¯å…¥å£ä½ç½®

a+(n+1)b+nc=2[a+(m+1)b+mc]æ•´ç†å¾—a+b=(n-2m)(b+c)ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä»è¿™ä¸ªç­‰å¼ä¸Šé¢å‘ç°ä»€ä¹ˆå‘¢ï¼Ÿb+cä¸ºä¸€åœˆçš„é•¿åº¦ã€‚ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´a+bç­‰äºn-2mä¸ªç¯çš„é•¿åº¦ã€‚

ä¸ºäº†ä¾¿äºç†è§£æˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹ä¸€ç§ç‰¹æ®Šæƒ…å†µï¼Œå½“n-2mç­‰äº1ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆa+b=b+cæ•´ç†å¾—ï¼Œa=c

æ­¤æ—¶æˆ‘ä»¬åªéœ€é‡æ–°é‡Šæ”¾ä¸¤ä¸ªæŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªä»headé‡Šæ”¾ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªä»ç›¸é‡ç‚¹é‡Šæ”¾ï¼Œé€Ÿåº¦ç›¸åŒï¼Œå› ä¸ºa=cï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä»–ä¿©å¿…ä¼šåœ¨ç¯å…¥å£å¤„ç›¸é‡ï¼Œåˆ™æ±‚å¾—å…¥å£èŠ‚ç‚¹ç´¢å¼•ã€‚

/** * Definition for singly-linked list. * struct ListNode { *     int val; *     struct ListNode *next; * }; */struct ListNode *detectCycle(struct ListNode *head) {    typedef struct ListNode ListNode;    ListNode* slow = head;    ListNode* fast = head;    while(1) {        // æ— ç¯        if(fast == NULL || fast->next == NULL) return NULL;        fast = fast->next->next;        slow = slow->next;        // è¯´æ˜æœ‰ç¯        if(slow == fast) {            break;        }    }    // fast é‡æ–°å‡ºå‘ï¼Œ slow ç»§ç»­åœ¨åŸä½ç½®ä¸Šå‡ºå‘ï¼Œå½“ä¸¤è€…å†æ¬¡ç›¸é‡æ—¶ï¼Œå…¶ä½ç½®å°±æ˜¯å…¥å£    fast = head;    while(fast != slow) {        fast = fast->next;        slow = slow->next;    }    return slow;}

class Solution {    public int search(int[] nums, int target) {        int left = 0;        int right = nums.length - 1;        while(left <= right) {            int mid = (left + right) / 2;            if(nums[mid] == target) {                return mid;            } else if(nums[mid] < target) {                left = mid + 1;            } else if(nums[mid] > target) {                right = mid - 1;            }        }        return -1;    }}

class Solution {    public int removeElement(int[] nums, int val) {        int slow = 0,  fast = 0;        for(; fast < nums.length; fast++) {            if(nums[fast] != val) {                nums[slow] = nums[fast];                slow++;            }        }        return slow;    }}

class Solution {    public int[] sortedSquares(int[] nums) {        int newArr[] = new int[nums.length];        for(int i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {            newArr[i] = nums[i] * nums[i];            // newArr[i] = (int)Math.pow(nums[i], 2);  æ³¨æ„powè¿”å›å€¼æ˜¯doubleï¼Œæœ‰ç±»å‹è½¬æ¢é—®é¢˜éœ€è¦è€ƒè™‘        }        Arrays.sort(newArr);        return newArr;    }}

  4. æ–°å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæ•°ç»„æ¥æ”¶å¹³æ–¹åçš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªä¸´æ—¶æŒ‡é’ˆ temp ä½äºè¯¥æ•°ç»„çš„ç»ˆæ­¢ä½ç½®

class Solution {    public int[] sortedSquares(int[] nums) {        int newArr[] = new int[nums.length];        int low = 0, high = nums.length - 1;        int temp = newArr.length - 1;        while(low <= high) {            int lowNum = nums[low] * nums[low];            int highNum = nums[high] * nums[high];            if(lowNum < highNum) {                newArr[temp--] = highNum;                high--;            } else {                newArr[temp--] = lowNum;                low++;            }        }        return newArr;    }}

class Solution {    public int minSubArrayLen(int target, int[] nums) {        int start = 0;        int end = 0;        int sum = 0;        int minLength = nums.length + 1;        for(; end < nums.length; end++) {            // ç»“æŸä½ç½®å‘å³ç§»åŠ¨            sum += nums[end];            // å½“å¤§äºæˆ–ç­‰äºTargetæ—¶ï¼Œå…ˆè®°å½•ä¸‹å½“å‰ç¬¦åˆè¦æ±‚çš„å­æ•°ç»„é•¿åº¦ï¼Œç„¶ååˆå§‹ä½ç½®å†ç§»åŠ¨            while(sum >= target) {                int currentLength = end - start + 1;                if(currentLength < minLength) {                    minLength = currentLength;                }                sum -= nums[start++];            }        }        return minLength == nums.length + 1 ? 0 : minLength;    }}

èºæ—‹çŸ©é˜µ II

  1. æ‰¾å‡†è¾¹ç•Œå€¼

class Solution {    public int[][] generateMatrix(int n) {        int[][] matrix = new int[n][n];        // å·¦å³        int left = 0, right = n - 1;        // ä¸Šä¸‹        int top = 0, bottom = n - 1;        int num = 1, target = n * n;        // å¡«å……        while(num <= target) {            // ä»å·¦å¾€å³            for(int i = left; i <= right; i++){                matrix[top][i] = num++;            }              top++; // æœ€å³è¾¹çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå·²ç»è¢«å¡«å……ï¼Œè¾¹ç•Œå¾€ä¸‹ç§»åŠ¨            // ä»ä¸Šå¾€ä¸‹            for(int i = top; i <= bottom; i++) {                matrix[i][right] = num++;            }            right--; // æœ€åº•ä¸‹çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå·²ç»è¢«å¡«å……ï¼Œè¾¹ç•Œå¾€å·¦ç§»åŠ¨            // ä»å³å¾€å·¦            for(int i = right; i >= left; i--) {                matrix[bottom][i] = num++;            }            bottom--; // æœ€å·¦è¾¹çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå·²ç»è¢«å¡«å……ï¼Œè¾¹ç•Œå¾€ä¸Šç§»åŠ¨            // ä»ä¸‹å¾€ä¸Š            for(int i = bottom; i >= top; i--) {                matrix[i][left] = num++;            }            left++; // æœ€ä¸Šè¾¹çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå·²ç»è¢«å¡«å……ï¼Œè¾¹ç•Œå¾€å³ç§»åŠ¨        }        return matrix;    }}
